standard_metadata.standard_description: Interpret the equation y = mx + b as defining a linear function, whose graph is a straight line; give examples of functions that are not linear.

hints.content: The equation is in *slope-intercept form* : $y=m\!\cdot\!x+b$. In this form, $m$ gives us the slope of the line and $b$ gives us its $y$-intercept.  So $y=-2x+5$ has a slope of $-2$ and a $y$-intercept at $(0,5)$.

We need two points. We already have the $y$-intercept $(0,5)$.  We can find a second point by reasoning about the slope. A slope of $-2$ means that when the $x$-value *increases* by $\purple{1}$, the $y$-value *decreases* by $\green{2}$.   $(0 \purple{+1},5 \green{-2})=(1,3)$    [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A coordinate plane. The x- and y-axes each scale by one. The points zero, five and one, three are plotted. There is a horizontal segment from zero, five to one, five that is labeled plus one. There is a vertical segment from one, five to one, three that is labeled minus two.

hints.content: Now we can graph the equation.  [[☃ grapher 1]]

The equation is in *slope-intercept form* : $y=m\!\cdot\!x+b$. In this form, $m$ gives us the slope of the line and $b$ gives us its $y$-intercept.  So $y=-3x+7$ has a slope of $-3$ and a $y$-intercept at $(0,7)$.

We need two points. We already have the $y$-intercept $(0,7)$.  We can find a second point by reasoning about the slope. A slope of $-3$ means that when the $x$-value *increases* by $\purple{1}$, the $y$-value *decreases* by $\green{3}$.  $(0 \purple{+1},7 \green{-3})=(1,4)$    [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A coordinate plane. The x- and y-axes each scale by one. The points zero, seven and one, four are plotted. There is a horizontal segment from zero, seven to one, seven that is labeled plus one. There is a vertical segment from one, seven to one, four that is labeled minus three.

hints.content: Now we can graph the equation.  [[☃ grapher 1]]

The equation is in *slope-intercept form* : $y=m\!\cdot\!x+b$. In this form, $m$ gives us the slope of the line and $b$ gives us its $y$-intercept.  So $y=-x-6$ has a slope of $-1$ and a $y$-intercept at $(0,-6)$.

We need two points. We already have the $y$-intercept $(0,-6)$.  We can find a second point by reasoning about the slope. A slope of $-1$ means that when the $x$-value *increases* by $\purple{1}$, the $y$-value *decreases* by $\green{1}$.   $(0 \purple{+1},-6 \green{-1})=(1,-7)$    [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A coordinate plane. The x- and y-axes each scale by one. The points zero, negative six and one, negative seven are plotted. There is a horizontal segment from zero, negative six to one, negative six that is labeled plus one. There is a vertical segment from one, negative six to one, negative seven that is labeled minus one.

hints.content: Now we can graph the equation.  [[☃ grapher 1]]

The equation is in *slope-intercept form* : $y=m\!\cdot\!x+b$. In this form, $m$ gives us the slope of the line and $b$ gives us its $y$-intercept.  So $y=x+4$ has a slope of $1$ and a $y$-intercept at $(0,4)$.

We need two points. We already have the $y$-intercept $(0,4)$.  We can find a second point by reasoning about the slope. A slope of $1$ means that when the $x$-value *increases* by $\purple{1}$, the $y$-value *increases* by $\green{1}$.   $(0 \purple{+1},4 \green{+1})=(1,5)$    [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A coordinate plane. The x- and y-axes each scale by one. The points zero, four and one, five are plotted. There is a horizontal segment from zero, four to one, four that is labeled plus one. There is a vertical segment from one, four to one, five that is labeled plus one.

hints.content: Now we can graph the equation.  [[☃ grapher 1]]

The equation is in *slope-intercept form* : $y=m\!\cdot\!x+b$. In this form, $m$ gives us the slope of the line and $b$ gives us its $y$-intercept.  So $y=2x-7$ has a slope of $2$ and a $y$-intercept at $(0,-7)$.

We need two points. We already have the $y$-intercept $(0,-7)$.  We can find a second point by reasoning about the slope. A slope of $2$ means that when the $x$-value *increases* by $\purple{1}$, the $y$-value *increases* by $\green{2}$.  $(0 \purple{+1},-7 \green{+2})=(1,-5)$    [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A coordinate plane. The x- and y-axes each scale by one. The points zero, negative seven and one, negative five are plotted. There is a horizontal segment from zero, negative seven to one, negative seven that is labeled plus one. There is a vertical segment from one, negative seven to one, negative five that is labeled plus two.

hints.content: Now we can graph the equation.  [[☃ grapher 1]]

The equation is in *slope-intercept form* : $y=m\!\cdot\!x+b$. In this form, $m$ gives us the slope of the line and $b$ gives us its $y$-intercept.  So $y=4x-9$ has a slope of $4$ and a $y$-intercept at $(0,-9)$.

We need two points. We already have the $y$-intercept $(0,-9)$.  We can find a second point by reasoning about the slope. A slope of $4$ means that when the $x$-value *increases* by $\purple{1}$, the $y$-value *increases* by $\green{4}$.  $(0 \purple{+1},-9 \green{+4})=(1,-5)$    [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A coordinate plane. The x- and y-axes each scale by one. The points zero, negative nine and one, negative five are plotted. There is a horizontal segment from zero, negative nine to one, negative nine that is labeled plus one. There is a vertical segment from one, negative nine to one, negative five that is labeled plus four.

hints.content: Now we can graph the equation.  [[☃ grapher 1]]

The equation is in *slope-intercept form* : $y=m\!\cdot\!x+b$. In this form, $m$ gives us the slope of the line and $b$ gives us its $y$-intercept.  So $y=\dfrac{3}{4}x+2$ has a slope of $\dfrac{3}{4}$ and a $y$-intercept at $(0,2)$.

We need two points. We already have the $y$-intercept $(0,2)$.  We can find a second point by reasoning about the slope. A slope of $\dfrac{3 }{4 }$ means that when the $x$-value increases by $\purple{4 }$, the $y$-value increases by $\green{3 }$.  $(0 \purple{+4},2 \green{+3})=(4,5)$    [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A coordinate plane. The x- and y-axes each scale by one. The points zero, two and four, five are plotted. There is a horizontal segment from zero, two to four, two that is labeled plus four. There is a vertical segment from four, two to four, five that is labeled plus three.

hints.content: Now we can graph the equation.  [[☃ grapher 1]]

The equation is in *slope-intercept form* : $y=m\!\cdot\!x+b$. In this form, $m$ gives us the slope of the line and $b$ gives us its $y$-intercept.  So $y=\dfrac{6}{5}x+1$ has a slope of $\dfrac{6}{5}$ and a $y$-intercept at $(0,1)$.

We need two points. We already have the $y$-intercept $(0,1)$.  We can find a second point by reasoning about the slope. A slope of $\dfrac{6 }{5 }$ means that when the $x$-value increases by $\purple{ 5}$, the $y$-value increases by $\green{6 }$.  $(0 \purple{+5},1 \green{+6})=(5,7)$    [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A coordinate plane. The x- and y-axes each scale by one. The points zero, one and five, seven are plotted. There is a horizontal segment from zero, one to five, one that is labeled plus five. There is a vertical segment from five, one to five, seven that is labeled plus six.

hints.content: Now we can graph the equation.  [[☃ grapher 1]]

The equation is in *slope-intercept form* : $y=m\!\cdot\!x+b$. In this form, $m$ gives us the slope of the line and $b$ gives us its $y$-intercept.  So $y=\dfrac{2}{3}x-4$ has a slope of $\dfrac{2}{3}$ and a $y$-intercept at $(0,-4)$.

We need two points. We already have the $y$-intercept $(0,-4)$.  We can find a second point by reasoning about the slope. A slope of $\dfrac{2 }{3 }$ means that when the $x$-value increases by $\purple{3 }$, the $y$-value increases by $\green{2 }$.  $(0 \purple{+3},-4 \green{+2})=(3,-2)$    [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A coordinate plane. The x- and y-axes each scale by one. The points zero, negative four and three, negative two are plotted. There is a horizontal segment from zero, negative four to three, negative four that is labeled plus three. There is a vertical segment from three, negative four to three, negative two that is labeled plus two.

hints.content: Now we can graph the equation.  [[☃ grapher 1]]

The equation is in *slope-intercept form* : $y=m\!\cdot\!x+b$. In this form, $m$ gives us the slope of the line and $b$ gives us its $y$-intercept.  So $y=\dfrac{4}{5}x-7$ has a slope of $\dfrac{4}{5}$ and a $y$-intercept at $(0,-7)$.

We need two points. We already have the $y$-intercept $(0,-7)$.  We can find a second point by reasoning about the slope. A slope of $\dfrac{4 }{5 }$ means that when the $x$-value increases by $\purple{5 }$, the $y$-value increases by $\green{4 }$.  $(0 \purple{+5},-7 \green{+4})=(5,-3)$    [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A coordinate plane. The x- and y-axes each scale by one. The points zero, negative seven and five, negative three are plotted. There is a horizontal segment from zero, negative seven to five, negative seven that is labeled plus five. There is a vertical segment from five, negative seven to five, negative three that is labeled plus four.

hints.content: Now we can graph the equation.  [[☃ grapher 1]]

The equation is in *slope-intercept form* : $y=m\!\cdot\!x+b$. In this form, $m$ gives us the slope of the line and $b$ gives us its $y$-intercept.  So $y=\dfrac{5}{3}x-9$ has a slope of $\dfrac{5}{3}$ and a $y$-intercept at $(0,-9)$.

We need two points. We already have the $y$-intercept $(0,-9)$.  We can find a second point by reasoning about the slope. A slope of $\dfrac{5 }{3 }$ means that when the $x$-value increases by $\purple{3 }$, the $y$-value increases by $\green{5 }$.  $(0 \purple{+3},-9 \green{+5})=(3,-4)$    [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A coordinate plane. The x- and y-axes each scale by one. The points zero, negative nine and three, negative four are plotted. The equation is in *slope-intercept form* : $y=m\!\cdot\!x+b$. In this form, $m$ gives us the slope of the line and $b$ gives us its $y$-intercept.  So $y=-\dfrac{1}{3}x+5$ has a slope of $-\dfrac{1}{3}$ and a $y$-intercept at $(0,5)$.

We need two points. We already have the $y$-intercept $(0,5)$.  We can find a second point by reasoning about the slope. A slope of $-\dfrac{1 }{3 }$ means that when the $x$-value increases by $\purple{3 }$, the $y$-value decreases by $\green{ 1}$.  $(0 \purple{+3},5 \green{-1})=(3,4)$    [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A coordinate plane. The x- and y-axes each scale by one. The points zero, five and three, four are plotted. There is a horizontal segment from zero, five to three, five that is labeled plus three. There is a vertical segment from three, five to three, four that is labeled minus one.

hints.content: Now we can graph the equation.  [[☃ grapher 1]]

The equation is in *slope-intercept form* : $y=m\!\cdot\!x+b$. In this form, $m$ gives us the slope of the line and $b$ gives us its $y$-intercept.  So $y=-\dfrac{1}{4}x+6$ has a slope of $-\dfrac{1}{4}$ and a $y$-intercept at $(0,6)$.

We need two points. We already have the $y$-intercept $(0,6)$.  We can find a second point by reasoning about the slope. A slope of $-\dfrac{1 }{4 }$ means that when the $x$-value increases by $\purple{4 }$, the $y$-value decreases by $\green{1 }$.  $(0 \purple{+4},6 \green{-1})=(4,5)$    [[☃ image 1]]

hints.content: Now we can graph the equation.  [[☃ grapher 1]]

The equation is in *slope-intercept form* : $y=m\!\cdot\!x+b$. In this form, $m$ gives us the slope of the line and $b$ gives us its $y$-intercept.  So $y=-\dfrac{4}{3}x+8$ has a slope of $-\dfrac{4}{3}$ and a $y$-intercept at $(0,8)$.

We need two points. We already have the $y$-intercept $(0,8)$.  We can find a second point by reasoning about the slope. A slope of $-\dfrac{4 }{3 }$ means that when the $x$-value increases by $\purple{3 }$, the $y$-value decreases by $\green{4 }$.  $(0 \purple{+3},8 \green{-4})=(3,4)$    [[☃ image 1]]

The equation is in *slope-intercept form* : $y=m\!\cdot\!x+b$. In this form, $m$ gives us the slope of the line and $b$ gives us its $y$-intercept.  So $y=-\dfrac{3}{2}x-3$ has a slope of $-\dfrac{3}{2}$ and a $y$-intercept at $(0,-3)$.

We need two points. We already have the $y$-intercept $(0,-3)$.  We can find a second point by reasoning about the slope. A slope of $-\dfrac{3 }{2 }$ means that when the $x$-value increases by $\purple{ 2}$, the $y$-value decreases by $\green{3 }$.  $(0 \purple{+2},-3 \green{-3})=(2,-6)$    [[☃ image 1]]

There is a horizontal segment from zero, negative three to two, negative three that is labeled plus two. There is a vertical segment from two, negative three to two, negative six that is labeled minus three.
